name: Margie Gilbert
text: We loved being able to see what this working boat had looked like when it was in action.  From the deck hands quarters to the kitchen and officers quarters, it was all interesting to see!  Make sure to check out the operation room! You can blow the boat's horn!

name: D H
text: What a surprise it was for us . We did not know that this boat even exist . On our way back home we decided  to stop at the dam for some pictures. There she was in her whole beauty . Sadly the place was already looked up so we couldn't go and explorer the inside . But the Mansion and the Snagboat  Montgomery are worth the visit

name: K Rogers
text: Nice peaceful diversion.  Worth the time if you are not far away and want to learn a little bit.  Picnic area nearby.  You can go on all over the snagboat and the visitors center (the 'house') is beautiful with several informational displays.  The staff is always very knowledgeable and helpful.

name: Sam Hill
text: So cool. Montgomery was replaced by Campbell. Campbell was replaced by General Irwin.

name: bill reischl
text: Not open when we were there.  Nice grounds.

name: Mike Carter
text: Great place to learn about a historical river and the maintenance requirements required for navigation.

name: Tawney Wade
text: loved this little out of the way place. Hope it attracts more visitors so they continue care of the place. I would suggest visit anytime but late summer... but it was a nice shady place to stop in the middle of the heat. Our granddaughter loved this place!

name: UAB/Brewer BREWER
text: Came with our family and friend. Friendly staff and it was a great educational experience. Got some GREAT pictures of the visitors center house.

name: Dave Butler
text: Interesting boat and pleasant place to spend some time. Could use a coat of paint though.

name: Kristen W.
text: Cool ship! Most of the doors inside are locked but you can see a few of the bunk rooms and all the equipment.

name: Chris Potter
text: Great trip with the kids.  Blow the horn!

name: Josh Cannon
text: It was very fun and entertaining

name: Bill Smith
text: Must see wonderful guide she was kind

name: Wayne Christensen
text:
How many snag boats are there? Do you know what one is? Do you know where they/it is? Here are some answers: Montgomery is a steam-powered sternwheel-propelled snagboat built in 1925 by the Charleston Dry Dock and Machine Company of Charleston, South Carolina, and operated by the United States Army Corps of Engineers. Montgomery cleared snags and obstructions from the Coosa, Alabama, Apalachicola, Chattahoochee, Flint, Black Warrior, and Tombigbee Rivers until her retirement from the Corps of Engineers on November 8, 1982. She was restored in 1984 and again in 2004, declared a National Historic Landmark in 1989. Montgomery now operates as a museum ship at the Tom Bevill Lock and Dam Visitor Center in Pickensville, Alabama.

My experience with the Monty was pleasant . . . for historical reasons and for architectural reasons and for engineering reasons. It represents a tool used long ago that I have never thought about and couldn't have imagined. It pulled stumps out of rivers and rivers-to-be. Cool stuff.
